Award.AwardTitle: Acquisition of Instrumentation to Support Earth Science Research with Near Surface Geophysical Technologies and to Engage Underrepresented Groups on Two Urban Campuses
Award.AbstractNarration:
1406430
Slater

This grant supports acquisition of a suite of near-surface field geophysical instruments to support research and research training at Rutgers University ? Newark and the City College of New York. Specific instrumentation that will be acquired includes: 1) a magnetometer; 2) borehole logging tools (e.g., gamma ray detector and magnetic susceptibility); 3) electromagnetic instrumentation; 4) a multi-channel seismograph; and 5) global positioning system (GPS) receivers. The requested instrumentation will support studies of carbon cycling in peatlands, groundwater-surface water interactions, solute transport in various geological settings, and biodegradation of contaminants in the subsurface that will benefit from various near-surface geophysical remote sensing modalities and precise positioning capability. The equipment will support research training and educational outreach activities at two urban academic institutions with a focus on engaging underrepresented students in geophysics, archaeological research, and applications of near surface geophysical imaging tools to urban environmental issues.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Summary:  This project supported the acquisition of critical instrumentation need to support continued research and education activities in near surface geophysics by the Department of Earth and Environmental Sciences (DEES) at Rutgers University Newark (RUN). The acquired instruments (primarily field geophysical instrumentation) replaced ageing geophysical sensors, upgraded existing instruments still in use and expanded the geophysical capabilities of RUN through purchase of instrumentation previously not owned by RUN. The project expanded opportunities for research and training in geophysics at two urban universities located within close proximity in the northern New Jersey/ New York City region and serving strong underrepresented minority (URM) student populations. Instruments were purchased over the three-year project duration and implemented in a wide range of research, education, technology transfer and professional development activities that impacted faculty, graduate students and undergraduates in near surface geophysics and associated geoscience fields.   

Intellectual Merit: RUN has a well-established research group (faculty, postdoctoral scientists and graduate students) pursuing basic research in geophysics coupled to developing novel applications of geophysical methods for improving understanding of subsurface hydrogeological and microbiological processes in the earth. Instrumentation purchased in this project substantially enhanced the capacity of RUN to further this research, which continues to be funded by a variety of federal agencies beyond just the National Science Foundation (NSF). This instrumentation allowed RUN to pursue new research in a variety of branches of hydrogeology, including remote characterization of hydrogeological properties, investigations of methane dynamics in peatlands and characterization of groundwater-surface water exchange processes in rivers. It also supported further research on geophysical sensing of biogeochemical processes in the subsurface, such as those associated with the degradation of contaminants released into the environment.

Broader Impacts: The acquisition of these instruments dramatically improved the geophysical infrastructure available at RUN. These instruments benefited faculty, graduate students and undergraduate students in multiple ways. Four faculty used these new instruments to further their research activities in NSG. Graduate students benefitted from access to these instruments to explore the questions forming PhD or MS graduate dissertation research. The project also supported professional development of graduate students who extensively used these instruments in education and community outreach-focused activities conducted through a student-organized society. Undergraduate and graduate students both benefitted from curricular enhancements (e.g. field-based experiential learning) resulting from implementation of these instruments into geophysics classes at RUN. Faculty and students at City College (NY) benefitted from unrestricted access to the equipment in support of their teaching and research needs. One faculty member at City College pursued sabbatical research at RUN resulting from the collaborations generated by this project. The project directly supported underrepresented minority (URM) students via a program of fellowships offered for participating in undergraduate research experiences in NSG. Four URM students were partly supported on funds provided by this project. One of these URM students was transformed by the research experience, choosing to go onto a PhD program in geophysics following completion of her undergraduate degree.
